Sports in disarray after devastating Nepal earthquakes
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) " A revered national sports coach is among the thousands of dead, trapped in his rented house when devastating earthquakes rocked Nepal.

The two recent earthquakes killed more than 8,300 people, and have had a devastating impact on all aspects of life in Nepal, including sports.

"He was a dedicated and experienced coach whose demise is a great loss for sports in Nepal."

"The tournament is vital for the future of Nepal's cricket and we plan to go to India for preparations."

Nepal may also lose the rights to host the 2015 Asian weightlifting championships, which were due to be held in Kathmandu from July 24-30.

All Nepal Football Association acting President Lalit Krishna Shrestha said he was uncertain when the league would resume because "we have been experiencing aftershocks every day."

The Asian weightlifting federation lists the championships as "to be confirmed" and has encouraged the Nepal organizers to host the 2016 championships instead.

"The AWF has requested us not to host the event and has proposed that we host the next edition in 2016," Partha Sarathi Sen Gupta, general secretary of the Nepal Weightlifting Association, said.

entry.title: Donor fatigue hits Nepal one month after mega earthquake, UN official says
entry.summary:
The international community's response to devastating earthquakes in Nepal has been disappointing, a United Nations official said on Monday, adding that donors were focusing more on reconstruction than much needed aid such as food and shelter.

"I am disappointed in the sense that there was such an impressive response in terms of search and rescue - all the teams that came in to do the work, they did very impressively and comprehensively - and maybe they think that's the job done," said Jamie McGoldrick, U.N. resident coordinator in Nepal.

Nepal's traditional donors were also more "development" focused and were likely holding back funds for long-term reconstruction and recovery projects, he added.

In Nepal, the devout see divine anger in the devastation wrought by massive earthquake
entry.summary:
Now, in the shadow of some of Nepal's holiest mountaintop temples, many find comfort in the notion that there was a divine and just cause behind the tragedy that has killed thousands and left hundreds of thousands more homeless and destitute.

"It's a warning from the gods to the politicians: Change yourselves, or who knows what will happen," said Ishwar Nath Yogi, the 51-year-old high priest at Gorkha Kalika, a revered temple to the goddess Kali and the birthplace of Nepal's first king.

Three-fourths of Nepal's 27 million people consider themselves Hindu, and the religion has a deep connection to this rugged Himalayan land dotted with countless temples and shrines.

entry.title: Magnitude-7.9 quake hits Nepal, causing big damage, injuries
entry.summary:
Nepal's Information Minister Minendra Rijal told India's NDTV station that there are reports of damage in and around Kathmandu but no immediate word on casualties.

Nepal suffered its worst recorded earthquake in 1934, which measured 8.0 and all but destroyed the cities of Kathmandu, Bhaktapur and Patan.

entry.title: Magnitude-7.9 quake hits Nepal, causing big damage, injuries
entry.summary: A strong earthquake shook Nepal's capital and the densely populated Kathmandu Valley before noon Saturday, causing extensive damage with toppled walls and collapsed buildings, officials said.

entry.summary: KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) - A bus plunged off a mountain highway near the Nepalese capital Wednesday, killing at least 12 Indian pilgrims and injuring 37 more, police said.

entry.title: Nepal marks anniversary of deadliest Everest avalanche
entry.summary: Buddhist Monks perform one-year death anniversary rituals for Ang Kaji Sherpa, a victim of last s deadly avalanche in Everest, at a monastery in Kathmandu, Nepal, Saturday, April 18, 2015.

entry.title: Nepal marks anniversary of deadliest Everest avalanche
entry.summary:
Nepal on Saturday marked the anniversary of Mount Everest's deadliest avalanche with a memorial and a government announcement that it will set up a welfare fund for mountaineering and trekking workers in the Himalayan nation.

The wife and a son of Aas Bahadur Gurung, one of victims of last year's avalanche in Everest, sit for a memorial organized by Nepal Mountaineering Association in Kathmandu, Nepal, Saturday, April 18, 2015.

entry.title: Nepal marks anniversary of deadliest Everest disaster with memorial, welfare fund for workers
Nepal marks anniversary of deadliest Everest avalanche
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) " Hundreds of people have gathered in Nepal's capital to mark the anniversary of the deadliest avalanche to hit Mount Everest.

On Saturday, the government announced that a portion of the permit fees charged to trekkers and mountaineers would be used for a fund to help people working in Nepal's trekking industry.

Also on Saturday, a memorial was held at the Nepal Mountaineering Association's office in Kathmandu, the capital.

entry.summary: His son, Sunil Bahadur Thapa, is Nepal's commerce and supply minister.

entry.title: 5-time Nepal Prime Minister Thapa dies at age 87
entry.summary: He served as Nepal's prime minister three times before 1990 when kings ruled the Himalayan state with a rubber-stamp parliament and a ban on political parties.

entry.title: Former Nepal Prime Minister Thapa dies at age 87
entry.summary:
KATMANDU, Nepal: An official says Surya Bahadur Thapa, who served as Nepal's prime minister five times, died in a hospital in India where he was being treated for stomach cancer.

He served as Nepal's prime minister three times before 1990, when the kings ruled the Himalayan state.

entry.summary: Wang said that the project is being undertaken at Nepal's request and that China has begun preparatory work.

entry.title: Digging under Everest: China eyes railway under world?s highest mountain
entry.summary:
"A proposed extension of the Qinghai-Tibet Railway to the China-Nepal border through Tibet would boost bilateral trade and tourism as there is currently no rail line linking the two countries," the state-run China Daily reported.

There is alarm in New Delhi that China's increasing role in the affairs of Nepal, Pakistan, the Maldives and Sri Lanka is a deliberate strategy to encircle India.

entry.title: China plans rail tunnel UNDERNEATH Mount Everest which would link the country with Nepal?
entry.summary: A tunnel could be built under Mount Everest as part of a new railway between China and Nepal, it has been revealed.

entry.title: Nepal's opposition cuts short crippling strike as constitution impasse drags on
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal - Life has returned to normal in Nepal after an opposition alliance cut short a crippling general strike over an impasse about how to approve the Himalayan nation's constitution.

Nepal has been without a constitution since 2008.

entry.title: Opposition Strike Shuts Down Nepal; Protesters, Police Clash
entry.summary: General strikes are a common tactic for the opposition in Nepal, and it is common for protesters to attack vehicles, shops and businesses that defy the calls to strike.

entry.title: Opposition-called general strike shuts down Nepal, as protesters clash with police
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal - A nationwide general strike enforced by opposition political parties has crippled life in Nepal, as protesters clashed with police and set vehicles on fire in the capital.

Schools were closed and markets shuttered across Nepal.

entry.title: Doctors in Nepal end strike, return to work
entry.summary: KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) - Thousands of doctors in Nepal have returned to work ending a strike after the government bowed to their demands.

entry.title: Nepal doctors stay away from work to support colleague
entry.summary: Dr. Govinda K.C., who is on a hunger strike, lies on a hospital bed at Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, April 1, 2015.

entry.title: Nepal doctors stay away from work to support colleague
entry.summary:
Thousands of doctors in Nepal stayed away from work at clinics and hospitals Wednesday to support a colleague who has been on a hunger strike for 10 days demanding reforms in medical education and services.

Only three of Nepal's 20 medical colleges are run by the government.

A group of doctors briefly scuffled with police officers while protesting outside the Nepal Medical Council office in Kathmandu, Nepal's capital.

entry.title: News24.com | Nepal doctors stay away from work
entry.summary:
More than 5 000 doctors took part in the action and only emergency services were open in hospitals across the Himalayan nation, said Dr Nirmal Rimal of the Nepal Medical Association.

The strike left most people in Nepal without access to doctors.

entry.title: Nepal official says climbers are returning to Mount Everest after last year's deadly avalanche
entry.summary: Nepal's government, which makes millions in permit fees, has been attempting to lure the climbers back.

entry.summary: KATHMANDU, Nepal - A Nepalese mountaineering official says climbers are returning to Mount Everest as the climbing industry recovers from last year's disaster on the world's highest peak.

entry.title: Wild rhino chased into forest after deadly rampage in Nepal
entry.summary: KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) - Forest officers and tamed elephants have chased a wild rhino back to the forest after it killed a woman and injured seven people in a rampage through a city in southern Nepal.

entry.title: Video shows rhino chasing motorbike down street in Nepal
entry.summary:
A local police official said the animal travelled some 20 kilometres from the unfenced reserve to the town of Hetaudu, in central Nepal, where it chased down startled pedestrians as well as vehicles.

Thousands of one-horned rhinos once roamed the plains of Nepal, but their numbers have plunged over the past century due to poaching and human encroachment of their habitat.

entry.title: Runaway rhino kills one, injures six in Nepal
entry.summary: Nepal, home to 534 rhinos, has twice been recognised by conservation experts for going a full year with no poaching incidents involving tigers or rhinos.

entry.title: Runaway rhino kills one, injures six in Nepal
entry.summary: Kathmandu: A rhinoceros that had wandered off a wildlife reserve rampaged through a town in central Nepal on Monday, leaving one woman dead and six people injured, police said.

entry.title: Charging wild rhino runs riot in Nepalese city (+ video)
entry.summary: Hetauda is about 80 kilometres south of Kathmandu, Nepal's capital.

entry.title: Wild rhino rampages in Nepal city, fatally gores woman
entry.summary: KATHMANDU, Nepal -- A wild rhino charged into a city in southern Nepal on Monday, killing a woman, injuring several others and chasing panicked people through the main market and a hospital, an official said.

entry.title: Rhino on rampage in Nepal, kills 1, injures several
Finnish climber, Nepalese guide die while descending from Mount Annapurna in Nepal
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal - A Finnish climber and his local guide died Wednesday while descending from the summit of Mount Annapurna in the first casualties of this mountaineering season, a Nepal mountaineering official said.

The climbers' deaths come as Nepal is trying to recover from last season's disaster on Mount Everest, when 16 local Sherpa guides were killed by an avalanche while carrying equipment and supplies for their foreign clients.

entry.title: Nepal soccer head stands down during FIFA financial probe
entry.summary: The 90-day sanction bars All Nepal Football Association president Ganesh Thapa from attending the Asian Football Confederation election congress in Bahrain on April 30.

entry.title: Nepal soccer head stands down during FIFA financial probe
entry.summary:
FIFA says Nepal's top soccer official has extended his self-imposed ban while the governing body's ethics committee investigates possible financial wrongdoing.

Thapa has led Nepal's soccer body for two decades.

entry.title: Everest Climbers Forced to Quit Last Year to Get New Permits
entry.summary: Nepal has cleared more than 300 mountaineers to climb Mount Everest after they had to abandon last year's efforts when an ice avalanche killed 16 guides in the mountain's deadliest disaster, an official said Friday.

entry.title: Nepal to give new Everest climbing permits to hundreds forced to quit after tragedy last year
entry.summary:
The head of Nepal's tourism department, Tulasi Gautam, says the government is extending last year's permits without charging new fees.

Nepal also pledged recently to improve weather forecasting, security and rescue efforts, and has cut climbing fees this year to $11,000 per climber from $25,000.

entry.title: Nepal jails man for 35 years for rape, murder of 7-year-old
entry.summary: Menuka Thapa of Raksha Nepal, an organization that supports sexually exploited girls in Nepal, said people are also more educated now and more cases are being reported.

entry.title: Nepal jails man for 35 years for rape, murder of 7-year-old
entry.summary:
A court in southern Nepal has sentenced a man to 35 years in prison for the rape and murder of a 7-year-old girl, officials said Wednesday, in a case that sparked outrage in the Himalayan nation.

The sentences are the maximum allowed for those offenses in Nepal.

Nepal does not have capital punishment.

There are conflicting data on sexual crimes in Nepal, but rights groups say the number of rape cases in the country has increased in recent years.

entry.title: Nepal boosts doctors, rescue efforts at Everest base camp
entry.summary: Nepal was criticized for not having a rescue plan during disasters or any government presence at the base camp despite charging climbers huge permit fees.

entry.title: Nepal boosts doctors, rescue efforts at Everest base camp
entry.summary: Four doctors, up from two or three in the past, will be stationed at the base camp's emergency room tent, which will be equipped to handle almost any medical need, said Devi Bahadur Koirala of the Himalayan Rescue Association Nepal.

entry.title: Nepal airport reopens after runway cleared
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) " Nepal's only international airport reopened four days after a Turkish Airlines jet skidded and blocked the single runway, the aviation authority said Sunday.

Nepal's government said it will wave visa fees for the stranded passengers.

entry.title: Turkish Airlines jet carrying 238 passengers crash lands after over-shooting runway in Nepal?
entry.summary: The only international airport in Nepal remained closed Wednesday morning after the accident.

entry.title: Turkish Airlines plane skids off Nepal runway
Too much human poo on Mount Everest says Nepal
entry.summary: Hundreds of foreign climbers attempt to scale Everest during Nepal's mountaineering season, which began this week and runs through May. Last year's season was canceled after 16 local guides were killed in an avalanche in April.

entry.title: Nepal official says human waste on Everest a major problem
entry.summary:
KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) " Human waste left by climbers on Mount Everest has become a problem that is causing pollution and threatening to spread disease on the world's highest peak, the chief of Nepal's mountaineering association said Tuesday.

He said Nepal's government needs to get the climbers to dispose of the waste properly so the mountain remains pristine.

Nepal's government has not come up with a plan yet to tackle the issue of human waste.
